name.value: The Game of the Pope and Pagan

item.description:
This game evolved from (or alongside) Fox & Geese and seems to have appeared first in Germany at least as early as 1803, where it has been known as Belagerungsspiel (Siege Game) or Festungsspiel (Fortress Game.) In English speaking countries it was published as Siege, or German Tactics. Since it is played on essentially a Fox & Geese board with additional markings and pieces, it was often included in a set with rules for Fox & Geese and Solitaire. The markings outline one nine-point side of the cross as a distinct fortress or castle, typically in a different color from the rest of the board's points. Also, the horizontal lines of the board are in a different color than the rest, but for the few closest to the fortress. This is to indicate where the attacker may not move; in some editions these markings are absent and instead simply described by the player's rules of movement.

The defending player has two pieces in the fortress, either on specific starting points or anywhere the player chooses, depending on the included rules. The other player has twenty-four pieces, one on each of the board's remaining points. The goal for the attacking player is to occupy all nine of the fortress points with one of his pieces. The goal for the defending player is to reduce the attacker to eight pieces, thereby preventing occupation of the fortress.

Attackers may move along the vertical or diagonal lines towards the fortress only, except on the few marked horizontal lines near the fortress. They may not jump or capture any pieces. The defenders may move in any direction along any line, and may capture (remove from the board) an attacker's piece by jumping over it to a vacant opposite point.

Siege evolved further into a larger edition with a sixty-seven point board, seventeen points for the fortress (and three defending pieces) and fifty points for the attackers. Sometimes published in Germany and continental Europe as Neues Belagerungsspiel (New Siege Game) or Grosses Festungs-Spiel (Big Fortress Game,) it was known in English-speaking countries as The Royal Garrison Game and has been published under many other names since then.

item.description:
Description from Khepher Games website:
"The party game where you're damned if you do, and even more damned if you don't! Players decide to answer the truth on the purple dice or act out the dare on the blue dice. If they fail, the black die reveals the penalty."

The game comes with two purple truth dice, two blue dare dice and a black die with dares that must be carried out if the truth or dare are not completed to the satisfaction of the rest of the players. All dice are six-sided and have text on them. The dice of the same colour combine to give an instruction, such as "Spank or grope ... An inanimate object".

The game doesn't actually specify an objective or how to win, but presumably the aim is to have the least embarrassing results after rolling ...

Amusingly, the game comes with the warning, "Not to be played with alcohol".
Miniatures rules for the English Civil War. Interestingly, this was the first product released by Tactical Studies Rules, which later became TSR, Inc.

Manila '45: Stalingrad of the Pacific (M'45), is a two-player, low-to-intermediate complexity wargame that simulates the American liberation of the capital of the Philippines in World War II, which took place from 3 February to 4 March 1945. To control complexity and present an overall-force-commander's-view of the battle, the game uses a tactically scaled map and units of maneuver coupled with an operationally scaled game turn length. The American player is generally on the offensive, trying to clear the entire Japanese defending force from the city prior to the end of the game.

Each game turn of M'45 equals three days. Each hexagon on the map represents 0.3 miles (0.5 km) from side to opposite side. The units of maneuver in the game are companies, batteries and battalions, representing anywhere from a about 100 to 1,000 men and their equipment.

Historically the Japanese fought to the last man (literally, not metaphorically), and the game's victory conditions represent that brutally absolute mindset. To determine the winner, both players examine the map at the end of Game Turn 10. If at that time there's one or more Japanese units still in play anywhere, the Japanese player is declared to have won the game. If there are no Japanese units left on the map at that time, the US player is declared to have won the game. Of course, if all Japanese units are wiped out prior to the end of the last game turn, play stops and the US player is declared the victor. No draws are possible.

Tacticians will enjoy the fact there are 22 unit types in the game: heavy artillery, heavy anti-aircraft, heavy mortar, heavy rocket artillery, naval infantry (armed ship crews), regular infantry, combat engineers, heavy weapons (machineguns), anti-aircraft, military police, anti-tank, field artillery, rear echelon ad hoc infantry, glider infantry, paratroopers, bridging engineers, mortars, armored cavalry, tanks, self-propelled artillery, amphibious tractors, and self-propelled anti-tank.

name.value: War of the Triple Alliance: Paraguay – 1865-1870

item.description:
The Triple Alliance War (TAW) is a two-player, low-to-intermediate complexity, strategic-level simulation of the second-largest war ever fought in the New World (the largest having been the American Civil War). The Paraguayan player is attempting to hold off the onslaught of three allied nations: Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay. The Allied player is generally on the offensive, attempting to win the game by invading Paraguay and seizing key areas on map within that country. The Paraguayan player is primarily on the defensive, but the situation also allows for his prosecution of offensives, particularly in the early stage of the war.

Game play encompasses the period that began historically in 1865 with the Paraguayans launching a preemptive strike into Argentine territory. The game ends during the first half of 1868 when, historically, the Allies broke through the Paraguayan river forts and went on to seize their capital. That advance signaled the ultimate doom of the Paraguayan cause and, though the war officially went on for another year and a half, that portion of it was more a rebellion-and-occupation struggle than an actual war.

Each hexagon on the map represents approximately 15.5 miles (25 km) from side to opposite side. The ground units of maneuver for both sides are primarily battalions, along with some nominal "brigades" and "divisions," which are actually all really battalion-equivalents themselves. Each riverine unit represents on naval combat vessel or several armed rafts or transport ships. Game Turn 1 represents three months, while each one after that represents half a year.

item.description:
Drive on Moscow (DoM) is a two-player, low-to-intermediate complexity, strategic-level simulation of the final German attempt to capture the capital city of the Soviet Union late in 1941. The German player is generally on the offensive, attempting to win the game by isolating or capturing Moscow, or by seizing all the other key cities on map. The Soviet player is primarily on the defensive, but the situation also requires that he prosecute local counterattacks.

Play encompasses the period that began with the Germans launching their offensive on 1 October 1941 and ends on 7 December of the same year. By that time it had become clear the invaders had shot their bolt without achieving their objective. Play may end sooner than the historic termination time if either player concedes defeat prior to the official end of a game.

Each hexagon on the map represents 7.5 miles (12 kilometers) from side to opposite side. The units of maneuver for both sides are primarily divisions, along with some brigades and one elite super-elite regiment. The effects of the general air superiority enjoyed by the Germans throughout much of the campaign are built into the game's movement and combat rules. Each game turn represents a week. The game uses a derivation of the well received system from our boxed game Drive on Stalingrad, 2nd edition.

Game Scale:
Game Turn: 1 week
Hex: 7.5 miles / 12 kilometers
Units: Brigades to Divisions

Game Inventory:
Two 22 x 34" full color map
Two dual-side printed countersheet (352 5/8" counters)
One 16-page rulebook

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Low-Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-15 hours

Players need to supply One 6-sided die

name.value: Sealords: The Vietnam War in the Mekong Delta

item.description:
Strategy & Tactics magazine #243.

SEALORDS: The Vietnam War in the Mekong Delta. (SL) is a low-to-intermediate complexity, two-player, operational simulation (with important tactical undertones) of riverine combat the Mekong Delta during the Vietnam War. There are two players: the Free World, including US, South Vietnamese and other allies; and the Communists, including Viet Cong and North Vietnamese Army forces. The objective of the Communist player is to infiltrate men and supplies via the Mekong Delta's many waterways, while also attacking critical Free World bases and towns across the region. The Free World player is attempting to prevent that infiltration while also conducting an offensive against Communist formations and bases.

Each player has available several types of riverine and ground units, as well as air units for the Free World player. The Communist player can make use of special rules representing that side's advantage in intelligence and local guerrillas. The system uses an 'operational impulse' system. That is, a player moves and fights with one of his forces, followed by his opponent doing the same with a force of the other side. Every operation requires the expenditure of command points.

SL has several different scenarios, each covering a critical period of operations: Game Warden (the early years), Tet (the Communist general offensive of 1968), and SEALORDS (the Free World counteroffensive of 1969-70).

Each map grid square equals 6.21 miles (10 km) across, and each full game turn represents a month. Units of maneuver are mostly battalions and battalion equivalents.

name.value: Wie weet hoe laat het is?

item.description:
Children can have fun while learning how a clock functions and how to tell the time. Step by step, children will become familiar with full hours, half hours, and minutes over the course of three games.

2004 edition: The game includes tiles each showing a clock set to specific times, and a big master clock where the hands can be set independently. Players must match the tiles to the time set on the master clock, focusing on memory, pattern recognition, and speed.

2001 edition: The game includes tiles each showing a clock set to specific times, and four big clocks where the hands can be set independently. Players must set their clock according to the tile drawn.

For ages 4-9.

name.value: On Our Way: Steps to Perfection

item.description: A game designed to acquaint individuals with some of the requirements of several gospel steps in the LDS church. Players roll dice to fill each requirement and chits are used on each players game sheet to mark the filled requirements. First player to fill all requirements on the game sheet wins.

name.value: Nauplion Board Game (Ancient Hellenic Board Game)

item.description:
Nauplion is an ancient city in Greece and also a board game of Nauplion's "Pessoi". Nauplion is the land of the ancient Troyan game creator "Palamides".

This is an ancient board game from the ancient city of Nauplion (Nau+plion = ship + ship) with boards and ancient Greek letters for 2-6 players. Each player has ancient letters from Nauplion Greece. Also there are three dice with the ancient shapes of Nauplion. Highest roll starts the game.

Nauplion has the following items:
1. Some Colorful Boards (Grids).
2. Ancient Hellenic Nauplion letters connected with numbers for each player.
3. Three dice with shapes.
4. Other materials.
5. A leaflet with some information for this game along with photos from the ancient Nauplion region.

In ancient Greece (Hellas) there was a very popular dice game with the name Cosmic Dice. 
At first at the Orpheus period was only three cosmic dice. 
At the Homeric period there were four dice. 
At last there were totally twelve dice, one for each one of the 12 Greek Gods.

The game comes with 12 cosmic dices and the explanation for predicting your future according to the ancient Greek philosophers.

Cosmic Dice has the following items:
1. A colorful grid.
2. 12 dice, each with ancient Greek scripts on each side.
3. A small book.
4. Many other items.

The full game which will be issued in the next version will have 25 "cosmic dice" and much more information about the ancient philosophy of fortune telling.

The new version will have 200 cosmic dice.

There is another game also Cosmic Runar Dice which is different and has the runic lettering and numbering.

Hus is played in Namibia by the Damara (Berg-Dama), Namaqua, Herero, Kanyama, Ndonga, Kwangari, Mbukushu, Shambyo and Hei||om in Namibia. It is also spelled ||hÅ«s. It is part of the Kalah Family of games.

The Hus edition published by Falke has a wooden board with 32 holes arranged in 4 rows. In Africa, versions exist with 8 - 24 holes.

In Africa, the larger boards are preferred by serious players.

More information:
http://mancala.wikia.com/wiki/Hus

name.value: Thomas the Tank Engine's Whistle Stop Surprise Card Game

item.description: A combination of a game and a puzzle. The game is a go fish type matching game, but the card backs also form a 2 foot by 4 foot puzzle. Play the game and then turn the cards over to make the puzzle.

"Linie" is played on a unusual board: 4 spiraled lines in 4 colors lead from every edge of the board to the center. These 4 spirals are intersected by 4 straight diagonals leading from the center to the edges.

The game includes 3 tokens per color/player, 1 die of each of these colors and 2 neutral white dice.

Movement is very unusual again, since a player can move any token on the board! During a turn, a player rolls 5-6 dice and each die roll allows the move of 1 token, using the white dice as jokers, who allow the movement of a token of any color.

Captures are possible on the diagonal lines only and the player who is the first to reach the center with all his 3 tokens is the winner of the game.

This card game consists of a huge deck of 132 cards and 25 letter chips.
100 of the 132 cards are coupons, showing a letter and a value of 10 or 50. The rest of the deck has 32 cards of 11 different types, such as gold-barrels, bank robbers, guards, policemen and others.

Before the game starts, 3 letter chips are drawn; they form the combination, which is needed to open the bank safe.

During the game, the players play cards on 3 different places of the table: their own playing area, the bank-safe or around the bank-safe (to protect the safe).

The game ends, when the bank safe is either opened with the correct combination or successfully robbed by a bank robber.

Points are calculated to determine the winner - the bank safe is likely to give the most points, but cards on the playing areas and cards still in the hands are calculated also.

Starchec is actually a 2-games box with 2 different games in it. Common to both games is the use of 6-sided chess-die showing the 6 chess symbols: knight, bishop, rook, pawn, queen and king. Each turn, the die is rolled and allows 1 playing piece to make a chess move according to the roll of the die.

Starchec-1, Wettlauf um die Sterne (race around the stars):


2-4 players can play. Each player has 1 "saucer" and 1 "meteor". Object of the game is to be the first player, who brings his saucer to the finish line. Meteors are used to block opponent saucer; they can only be moved, when a king is rolled, but the can be placed everywhere on the board then. If a saucer captures another saucer, the 2 involved saucers just change places.

Starchec-2, Spiel im Weltall (game in outer space):


This game is played on a normal chessboard. Each of the 2 players has 8 tokens, which are placed on two opposing sides of the board. Winner of the game is the player, who brings all 8 tokens on the opposing side of the board first. Captures result in an exchange of positions again, but it's also allowed to "capture" own pieces, if a player does not want to move any of his tokens.

The gameboard shows 5 rows of 8 spaces. The rows are numbered from 100-500 and marked 500-2500 at the side.

The 40 spaces of the board are filled with 1 coin of different values. During a turn, a player must take 1 coin from the bottom and he can place any number of coins back. When a coin is placed back on the board, the sidewards marked amount of money is collected.

Winner of the game is the player who has earned 50,000 first.

Apparently developed from The Economy Game reducing it to the pure and basic mechanism.

A three dimensional palm tree contains a number of coconuts in different colors. The goal is to climb up to the top of the palm with your ape by clever use of the coconut counters.

There are a number of chits; most show a coconut, a few an elephant. The player in turn flips a chit. If it shows a coconut, he may climb up to the next one with the same color. If it shown an elephant, he falls back a bit.

A good memory is necessary to know where the best coconuts are. The chits are moved from one area into the other each time they are displayed, and you can't use the same chip again until all of the chits have been used.

This game was published as a supplement for Fairplay, a German print magazine for games. Wahlparty is a small booklet and you have to cut all cards and built a box out of the booklet by yourself.

Wahlparty is an election game in the political system of "Bundesrepublik Deutschland". You have to collect set of card for 16 federal states and gain the majority.

In a world where heroes are an everyday sight, do you have what it takes to fight for your time in the limelight? Can you prove your powers and abilities or are you just another weirdo in spandex?

In The Supers, you decide just that! The Supers is a fast paced, easy to learn card game for 2 to 6 players! Build your own hero with the help of a variety of Powers, Gadgets, Tactics and Places and take on your friends in a head-to-head, one on one battle or get six (or more!) people together for a battle royale!

For years, players of fantasy games have stormed the dungeons and strongholds of evil sorcerers, warlords, and just plain bad guys as heroes: knights, wizards, druids, paladins, and more. Heroically they have braved the darkest pits, the foulest creatures, and the most perilous of quests.

This, however, is not such a game.

Welcome to The Imp Game! Rather than taking on the role of one of these namby-pamby heroes, players in the Imp Game take on a much more entertaining role: that of the common, dungeon imp! Servants of a wannabe dark and quasi-evil overlord, players scour the world in search of items of power, foil the plots of “evil” Adventurers, and clean out the dungeons whenever needed, getting themselves into mess after mess with the only way out is to help each other!

The Imp Game is a wonderfully hilarious game for 2 to 5 players of all ages. The Imp Game features a powerful "Failure" mechanic that captures the feeling of inept but stupidly lucky sidekicks, ensuring that success is inevitable, but who succeeds at what?

Self-producted fantasy boardgame.

Every player has a character represented by a counter on the game map.

Players try to increase the features (strength, agility, stamina, mind and... money) of their characters according to the classical fantasy setting (wander, have encounters, fight the monsters, take the gold).

The final goal is to find and piece together the fragments of the Wand and become ruler of the lands.

Rules and cards are only in Italian.

"Terre Invisibili" means "Invisible Lands" in English.

item.description:
"Wehrmacht:Fifth Blitzkrieg" There are two 59 x 84 cm map stretching from Leningrad (included) to the Caucasus, so the whole Eastern Front, except the Finnish front and a bit of the most Western parts of the Soviet Union which were overrun in Summer 1941 at the beginning of Operation Barbarossa (printed in Japanese) and 22 pages of rules (in Japanese). 
720 counters: units are divisions for the Germans and Axis allies plus separate tiger tank companies, tank and infantry armies, tank, mechanized and cavalry corps for the Soviets. Players can play from May 1942 to March 1943, the battle of Kharkov of May 1942, Operation Blue on June 1942 or the Russian counterattack of November 1942 leading to the Stalingrad encirclement and von Manstein counter stoke of February-March 1943. 
Very beautiful components.

For one or two players. 
Playing time: about eight hours.

Space Checkers is a strategy game for two to four players, ages 8 to adult. Each player tosses two dice, one that indicates the number of spaces to move (1 to 6), and the other that indicates which direction to move (East, West, North, South, or WILD).

Additionally, you can warp your playing pieces from one side of the board to the other (Horizontal and Vertically).

To win, just capture ten of your opponent’s playing pieces.

Approximate playing time is between 30 and 60 minutes — depending on the number of players.

item.description:
HI! I am the Pig and I am HAPPY near the Farm and near the Water. If I stop on other places... I become SAD! When Happy I can draw the YELLOW HAPPY NUMBERS, and when Sad I can draw the PURPLE SAD NUMBERS!

MOOO! I am the Cow and I am HAPPY near the Farm and near the Grass: On these places I can draw THREE HAPPY NUMBERS and if i draw a "+", then I can sum them! With 5 + 4, I can move up to 9 squares!

Who will be an HAPPY ANIMAL?
Who will arrive first? Maybe someone will stop on a square to stay happy and draw the HAPPY NUMBERS, higher than the SAD NUMBERS! 
The choice is yours: always run till the last step or stay happy and win!

HAPPYANIMALS is a COMPLETE GAME
for 2-18 players, 5 years and up. Contents:
- 18 Cards with the characteristics of all Animals
- 18 Counters of the Animals, The Happy Numbers and the Sad Numbers
- 1 Board representing the race map with the Farm, the Woods, the Grass, the Water...
- 1 Rule sheet easy (draw and move) and one with addictions, subtractions, multiplications and divisions.
- And... 2 wooden PUSH PUPPETS!

All the 18 wooden push puppets are available: 
Pig, Cow, Lion, Donkey, Elephant, Dog, Cat, Giraffe, Gazzelle, Husky, Leopard, Green Dog, Bear, Sheep, Monkey, Bamby, Horse, Zebra.

Push puppets are wonderful handmade and hand-painted animals that when "Happy" stands on their base, when "Sad" flop on their legs!

HAPPYANIMALS will be premiered as prototype at EssenFair 06, Stand SilToys booth number 9-19 and at stand Angelo Porazzi Games booth number 9-28.

Each player secretly places his collection of tiles face down on a triangular board. The covered half of the tiles have different colors and different denominations. Each denomination must be placed in a certain pattern on the board. Players then turn over the tiles on other boards, earning a multiple of the denomination. Red tiles score for the player who turned over the tile, black tiles score for the player who owns the tile. Each turn ends when a black tile is uncovered. The game ends when all tiles have been uncovered, and the player with the most money wins. This is an interesting but (seemingly) forgotten game from one of the largest publishers. The game is similar to Battleship, but with much more depth.

NAQ, pronounced "Knack", is a party game where all players become trivia buffs because the trivia is based on the knowledge of the players in the game. A fun, fast-paced party game where you can mix people with different levels of education and cultures with everyone having an equal chance of winning. More information available at http://www.naqgames.com/index2.html

From the back of the box:

Now, you can be a Global Investor! Buy and sell currencies, properties, commodities, production plants and shops. Collect rent and make profits. Yes, make a billion dollars! But to win, you n eed to make good decisions, form partnerships, be prudent, take risks; and, most of all, have balance in your life. So,.. Go.. get it!

Investing is... "The greatest game in the world" according to Mr. Barton Briggs, head of Morgan Stanley Asset Management, and one of the world's biggest international money managers.
This boardgame deals with issues related to the world economy and global investment. Design for
- families who love to play together,
- parents who wish to impart values and skills for future success,
- students for interactive learning, and
- friends in a mood for indoor fun.

INVE$TOR is:
Educational - young people learn about global economic issues, market trends and money management. They learn to plan ahead, make wise decisions, change with the times, take calculated risks, form partnerships, and have a balanced life.
Fun and Entertaining - the whole family, and friends, of ages 12 & up, may enjoy interacting, collaborating and competing with one another through a game that is never the same everytime you play it!

I Spy Bingo is a bingo game based on the 'I Spy' picture books by Walter Wick and Jean Marzollo. The bingo boards (4 space by 4 space) are double-sided - one side with the letters in sequence for beginning players and the reverse side with randomly arranged letters. Each bingo card square contains pictures of objects beginning with the letter in the square. The letter cards are also two-sided - the beginner's side features the letter to be called out, and the "advanced" side only contains pictures whose names are to be called out and the first letter of the word used. Per the game box, ages 4+ are appropriate for the game.

From the game box: "Popular I Spy pictures become a fast and fun bingo game...get 4 in a row and shout Bingo!
 * Players learn beginning sounds and practice reading skills.
 * Promotes manual dexterity, verbal and visual skills.
 * Two levels of play."

item.description:
In Stranded, Time Machine travel takes you to great events in American history! From the Mayflower's landing at Plymouth Rock to the Wright Brothers' takeoff at Kitty Hawk. From Paul Revere's biggest date to the Gold Rush of '48. But the trick is: getting from one to the other without getting stuck! Fun and suspense mount as every move makes return to the present a little bit tougher. Simple but well-timed strategies are key to being the last remaining player and winner of the game. Fast-paced, friendly, and educational too, STRANDED is for 2 to 4 players, ages 8 to adult. Approximate playing time is 30 minutes.

Contents: 1 Game Board, 1 Set of Rules, 4 Movers, 1 Color Die, and 48 Colored Time Machine Circles.

item.description:
The game involves placing wooden pieces on a tower, each piece consisting of a line of 5 colored cubes in different arrangements, so that each piece touches the piece(s) below it only where the colors match. The player who is unable to place a piece or who knocks the tower down is eliminated.

The game comes with a solid wooden plinth to place the first piece on, 60 wooden pieces and a large cloth bag to draw them from.

"There is a job open in hell for a nasty devil like you. But you has grown to like working on earth and desperately wants to avoid going down to hell again. You must be bad enough to keep your job, but not bad enough to get a new job. A devilish challenge."

A card game made by a new Swedish designer.

From the Website:

"You are only Traffic Controller at Edward C. Eagle Airport and there are zillions of planes coming your way.

You would scream if you were not busy directing planes. "

A game of panic control.

Each player is playing a Traffic Controller and the goal of the game is to be the last traffic Controller left in the game. You must make sure that no planes collide, easier said than done.

item.description:
From the Rules:
"Feeeeed Meeeee is the most popular game among the Big Trolls. The rules are simple: Big Trolls sit around a table loaded with food.. but they are not allowed to eat! As time passes, they get hungrier and hungrier. The first Big Troll that can´t control his hunger and starts to eat the food is the loser"

You must collect sets of food cards. This is done by rolling 2 dice to determine how many action points you get for the turn. With these action points you move to different storage places and collect food.

The Swedish edition, called Glufs Glufs, was included in issue 5/2006 of the Swedish games magazine Fenix.

Knatsch - the tournament play 
for 3 to 5 players, approx.. 20 minutes.

A New Print & Play Game From Michael Schacht on his Spiele aus Timbuktu Web site.

Once in the year the king organizes a gigantic tournament. The participants argue about the favor of the castle and about the profit of castles. The player with most points of fame wins the tournament.

item.description:
Scrabble Junior: The Disney Edition is (as the name would suggest) a Disney-themed version of the Scrabble Junior family. The game features a two-sided gameboard and 101 letter tiles. The words to be created are printed on the gameboard, and the players take turns placing up to two letters per turn onto those words, always placing the next letter of the word in order. Points are scored for being the player to place the letter tile that completes a word. The game is obviously aimed at children (ages 5+, per the box).

From the game box: "Match up letters to create popular Disney words! Can you spell out Jasmine? Or maybe you can finish the word Simba. Use your letter tiles to build crosswords on the picture-filled game board. Each time you finish a word, you get a scoring chip. When all of the tiles are played, the one with the most chips wins! Have twice the fun with the two-sided board. Flip over the board and build words like Mirror and Fawn."

item.description:
An analysis of "matrix games" where each player has a set of "strategies" to choose from - these are just labels, could be rock/paper/scissors - and there are pre-arranged "payoffs" according to which strategies are chosen. Prisoner's Dilemma is a well-known example of such a "game". Or, consider the following example, paraphrased from the text.

Aldie and Derk decide to play a game for daiquiris. Each throws one or two fingers. If both throw one finger, Aldie buys Derk a daiquiri. If both throw two fingers, Derk buys Aldie two daiquiris. If they don't match, Aldie pays Derk a dime. (At the time this book was written, daiquiris were 55 cents.) How much per game should Derk demand of Aldie in order to make this game worthwhile?

This text can help you solve this problem, or others like it. In particular, this is the type of game theory floating around behind certain sports simulations like Football Strategy or MLB SportsClix, although the latter has dice as well as the strategy selection.

This game appears to be one of a set of games that were produced in small, matchbox sized boxes. The game looks like a small book, and has Vol 1. on the spine, which suggests that there may be others in the set. There is no publication date, but this is probably fairly old.

A Mexican trivia game that was quite popular some years ago. Up to six players or teams can play. The players advance in a track of 42 spaces (or "kilometers", hence the name of the game) by answering questions about six main themes. A black piece represented the runner from the "Ignorance Country", a special player that advances every time nobody answers a question.

Because of the game's popularity, more editions were published: "Maratón Junior", for younger players with easier questions; "Maratón de los Famosos", with questions about celebrities of TV, sports, and music; "Mi primer Maratón", a very basic edition for children; and "Maratón con Opciones", a variant with 3 answers for each question, where players try to choose the correct option.

item.description:
The object of this game is to plant the tulip garden before the moon is full. Each turn the player rolls the dice and can plant a tulip of the color rolled. If the moon is rolled, the player must add a moon piece to the central moon puzzle. If the moon is complete before any gardens are planted then the moon wins.

The game has a co-operative aspect in that if a player rolls a tulip color that they already have in their garden then they may donate the tulip to a different player. No player may have two tulips of the same color in their garden.

The game is crafted from wooden components.

Abstract strategy game created for the "Learn & Play a New Game" tournament held during FirenzeGioca (="FlorencePlays") 2006

It is freely downloadable.

name.value: Tri-Memo: The Lord of the Rings – The Two Towers

item.description: This game is an average run of the mill memory game with a twist. In the game you are trying to match characters from the Lord of the Rings Two Towers movie. Instead of finding a matched pair on your turn you must find a matched trio of pictures. This makes the game somewhat more difficult than the traditional matched pair style of gameplay. Don't fret though, rules are included to play the routine memory style game of matching pairs. The game was published by BETEXA which is in the Czech Republic. FEVA, located in the United Kingdom, was the distributor. This game is hard to find and most likely would appeal to collectors of Lord of the Rings themed games.

Goalsystem Fantasy (GSF) is a complete fantasy skirmish system designed for 28mm miniatures play. It features the basics of combat, movement, and character creation. The game also includes rules for magic and scenarios. GSF is powered by the Goalsystem, the same rules that run SuperSystem and Chaos In Cairo. If you have never tried a Goalsystem game, this is a great way to do it. All you need are 3-5 figures per side, and a handful of six-sided dice. Color cover and fifteen pages.

From the rules: "If you don't know or understand bowling, this game will teach you. If you do know bowling, this game will be a challenge to your knowledge and ability."

Simplistic playing card driven game. I believe I got the games from Pop-Tart boxes. I am aware of 8 games in the series.

From the rules: "If you don't know or understand basketball, this game will teach you. If you do know basketball, this game will be a challenge to your knowledge and ability."

Simplistic playing card driven game. I believe I got the games from Pop-Tart boxes. I am aware of 8 games in the series.

Contents
 * 2 Game Boards
 * 48 Colored Plastic Marbles - 6 each of 8 colors 
 * 1 Indicator Shaker
 
Aim of the game:
To set up as many patterns as possible on your individual board, that match the little shaker pattern.

Crossword game. Cards provide categories and three different grids allow for different levels of play. Players fill in the blank grids "across" first for five points each and then add "down" answers for ten points each. A bonus is added for completing the grid. Includes pads of grids, pencils, eraser and "egg timer".

name.value: Rockets Away: Sensational Space Travel Game
Eroi del Futuro: Sensazionale viaggio tra i pianeti

item.description: In this classic game from the 1950s, players take turns launching rockets at a board containing futuristic space settlements and various celestial objects, such as planets, stars, and a sun. Launching occurs by placing the rockets in rocket launcher attached to a space station and then dropping the rockets on the board from above. Players score points or lose points based on where the rockets land. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins.

name.value: Steve Scott Space Scout: A Game of Adventure in Outer Space

item.description: In this game, players select a color for their rockets and then go on a mission to explore the solar system.

name.value: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Card Game

item.description: Civilization: The Card Game simulates the rise of empires as in the computer game Civilization. Players will collect resources, obtain lands, construct Buildings and Wonders, discover Technologies, and fight enemies on their way to victory. The game ends when the final Technology is bought, and the player with the most Victory Points (one each per Wonder, Technology, and Population) is declared the Winner. If Victory Points are tied, then the Winner is the player with the most Technologies. If Technologies are tied, then the Winner is the player with the most Population.

item.description:
This game is a race to the finish. Several pitfalls and twists and turns await your journey home. This game is similar to an advanced chutes and ladders as some paths let you skip past sections and others send you back. Action cards also affect your play along the way.

The board itself is a giant puzzle and comes in 6 large pieces that fit together to form the board.

A simulation of one-on-one basketball featuring NBA stars, playground greats, Harlem Globetrotters, and other famous players. Players are rated for five different shot types (jump, back-in, power, shake-n-bake, and drive), their ability to get a shot off for, their chance of making the shot, ability to defend each type of shot and overall defense, rebounding, blocks, steals, free throws, dunks and more. 308 players are rated for the game.

Schuss looks like it is becoming the new choice of after-dinner board gamers, pushing Trivial Pursuit off the table.

The board itself is designed like a piste map, with blue runs throwing up easy Alpine-related questions, with tougher questions on the testing blacks. Mountain restaurant stops help you to change runs and wipe-outs can have 'hilarious consequences' - with dares (why not make up your own?) in order for fallers.

Box Contents:
Mountain shaped playing board (60 x 40cms)
6 wooden playing pieces + 1 die
1 wooden shaker +1 wooden card holder (inspired by the shape of a bobsleigh!)
Schuss question cards (120 blue, 120 red and 120 black questions)
30 Schuss mountain restaurant cards
40 Schuss wipe-out dare cards (including 5 blanks to add your own dares!)

http://www.schuss.co.uk/

Energy as a concept is not easy; scientists believe that the amount of energy in the universe is constant, not used up, but converted from one form to another. The original science through literacy resources (shown opposite) followed a family’s day and all the different types of energy they encountered: a day full of energy – from the energy inside them, to that found and used around them. Stimulating young children to understand the value of energy and how not to waste it, is vital. This boardgame has been developed as an extension to the resource pack and posters, following requests from teachers already using the material.

The game has been designed for use within the primary school, linking science and literacy at various skill levels. On the following pages, are not only background information, facts and ways to play the game, but also suggested variations and ideas for follow up activities.

Anno Domini 947 a. C. marks the royal marriage between Lothar II, King of Italy, and Adelaide of Burgundy. Unfortunately, soon after this union is sadden due to the death of the King. The belief is that the King was killed by Berengario II, Marquis of Ivrea, hungry to reign the Kingdom. Adelaide, indignant, opposes this new regency, as Berengario II tries to force her to marry his own son, Adalbert of Ivrea. She runs away to seek refuge in the Canossa Castle, strategic in its position, owned and governed by Azzo Adalbert. Here comes the siege of the castle, and this is what we are going to recall: on one side Berengario II and his son, Adalbert, are besieging, and on the other Adelaide of Burgundy and Azzo Adalbert are under siege; in defense of them comes Otho I, Emperor of Germany, with his knights. Each courageous player will guide 2 of the Emperor’s knights, to try to free Adelaide, allowing Otho I to marry her in 952, and thus becoming the new King of Italy.

Goal of the game is to achieve a higher score than your opponents. Points are achieved by either taking enemy tiles or creating a way out of the Canossa Castle (3 points).
Enemy tiles, like all other tiles, are captured when you place one of your knight-pawn on one of them. Captured tiles must always be perfectly visible to all other players.
The game ends when a player creates a way out of the Canossa Castle (that means to seize the Canossa Castle tile).
In order to seize the Canossa Castle tile or any other enemy tile players must create a way out that enables that tile, on which there’s the knight-pawn, to be moved off of the board.

item.description: "Lowcy Zwierzat" (or "Animal hunters") is a print and play game where players move their pieces (hunters) on a hexagonal desert. Once 4 hunters are next to a hex with an animal that animal is captured by the player who has most hunters nearby. Hunters move one hex at a time unless they manage to form a group, which allows them to move about much more quickly.

item.description:
The Synestructics company sold the building toy of the same name, which was a set of hollow rods of various lengths and connectors with various numbers of prongs, which together could be combined to build three-dimensional frameworks.

NetResults is a game which uses Synestructic pieces - one type of connector and one size of rod (in three colors). Starting with a simple triangle, players take turns adding pieces to a common structure, attempting to complete polygons of any shape. Points are awarded for the polygons based on the number of edges, with extra points awarded for completing polygons that use pieces from other players.

The game can be played by 2-3 players as individuals and 4 or 6 players in teams of two.

item.description:
This game was published in the May 1971 issue (Volume 3, Number 5) of Spartan International.

As indicated by the title, it is a wargame covering the fighting for Arnhem from September 17-25, 1944. It uses a fairly simple system, but does cover the salient points of the operation, including parachute drops, supply (including parachuted supplies), bridge blowing, etc.

In addition to the rules, the magazine includes an 11"x17" black and white map, an Order of Appearance sheet, 83 blue counters (German units and blown bridge markers), 44 beige counters (Allied units, air attack markers, and dropped supply markers), plus 1 more counter in each color which may or may belong to this game (the picture on each looks something like a mine). The counters are on paper and must be mounted and cut out

This game was published in the May 1971 issue (Volume 3, Number 5) of Spartan International.

It is a tactical naval game of the 1941 battle between the Bismarck and Prinz Eugen on one side and the Hood, Prince of Wales, Suffolk, and Norfolk on the other. It is really a set of miniatures rules, with counters provided to be used instead of ship miniatures. Six counters are included (one for each ship), sized for 1:1200 scale.

name.value: Pythagoras Board Game (Ancient Hellenic Board Game)

item.description:
Ancient Greeks invent the board games (petties) and the most famous was "Pessoi" in many eras and with many differences.

Pythagoras of Samos is often described as the first pure mathematician. He is an extremely important figure in the development of mathematics yet we know relatively little about his mathematical achievements. Unlike many later Greek mathematicians, where at least we have some of the books which they wrote, we have nothing of Pythagoras's writings. The society which he led, half religious and half scientific, followed a code of secrecy which certainly means that today Pythagoras is a mysterious figure.

Pythagoras is the recreation of the Pythagorian "Pessoi".
This is a real ancient boardgame from ancient Hellas.

There is one board. 
There are 2-6 players. 
Each player has pawns. 
Pawns must have the signs of ancient Greek letters. 
Also there are three dice with ancient Greek shapes on them.
The player with the highest die roll plays first. 
All pawns must enter the board make a word.

The board game Pythagoras has the following items:
1. A Colorful Board.
2. Pawns/letters different in color and shape for each of the players.
3. One to Three dice with different shapes on each one.
4. Many other items.

name.value: Macedonia Board Game (Ancient Hellenic Board Game)

item.description:
Macedonia is an ancient region in Greece and also a board game of the "Pessoi".

The theme here is Greek Macedonia, one of the most beautiful regions of Greece, and an area which will grow in importance as the commercial and cultural center of the Balkans in the years to come.

This is an 2-6 player board game styled on ancient Macedonia with boards (petties) and ancient Greek letters from the Macedonian era. Each player has ancient letters from ancient Macedonia Greece. Also there are three dice with the ancient Macedonian shapes. Highest roll starts the game.

Macedonia has the following items:

1. Some Colorful Boards (Grids).
2. Ancient Hellenic Macedonian letters connected with numbers for each player (Aristotelian method).
3. Three dice with different shapes.
4. Other materials.
5. A leaflet with some information for this game along with photos from the ancient Macedonian region.

name.value: Byzantium Board Game (Ancient Hellenic Board Game)

item.description:
Byzantium is the name given to both the state and the culture of the Hellenic Empire in the middle ages. Both the state and the inhabitants always called themselves Hellenes/Roman, as did most of their neighbors. Western Europeans, who had their own Roman Empire. The eastern Europeans called them Orientals or Greeks (Hellenes). Byzantion was the ancient name of the capital city and Byzantines gives the name of the Empire's capital city, as Constantinople (City of Constantinos the Emperor).

Byzantium is an ancient city in Greece and also a board game of Byzantium's "Pessoi".
This is an ancient board game from the ancient city of Byzantium with boards depicting the Byzantine era. Byzantium also called the Constantinople. Played with Byzantine Greek era letters for 2-6 players.
Also there are three dice with the ancient shapes of Byzantium.
Highest roll starts the game.

Byzantium has the following items:
1. Some Colorful Boards (Grids).
2. Byzantium letters connected with numbers for each player.
3. Three dice with shapes.
4. Other materials.
5. A leaflet with some information for this game along with photos from the Byzantine era.

name.value: Cosmic Runar Dice (Ancient Hellenic Dice Game)

item.description:
Cosmic Runar (Runic) Dice

In ancient Europe there was a very popular dice game with the name Cosmic Runar (Runic) Dice. At first at the Orpheus period was only three cosmic dice. At the Homeric period there were four dice. At last there were totally twelve dice, for the 12 Gods. The Europeans create the runar (runic) scripts, so the Cosmic Runar Dice created.

The game comes with 12 cosmic runar dice and the explanation for predicting your future according to the ancient Greek and European philosophers.
Also given is an explanation of how to use this game as a Rune Casting and fortune telling according to the scripts.

Cosmic Runar Dice has the following items:
1. A colorful grid.
2. 12 dice with runar (runic) scripts and letter.
3. A small book.
4. Many other items and a research book about runar script.

The full game which will be issued in the next version will have 25 cosmic dice and much more information about the ancient philosophy of fortune telling.

This board game have been proposed to The UK Parliament for Olympic games in London 2012.

Apparently, the first wargame made in France. Published by the designer (Jean-Pierre Défieux) in 1977.

Very simple French wargame about the famous battle. It uses the simple attacker/defender odds table with elimination, retreat or "exchange". No command system, no special rules, a good game to introduce novices to concept of ZOC, combat odds, movement points...Large color map, basic NATO counters blue for French, green for Russians and white for Austrians.

item.description:
Shatranj is the predecessor to modern European Chess. The two games resemble each other, but Shatranj is different enough that they can be considered two distinct games, even though it is Shatranj that Europeans first called "chess".

The main differences between shatranj and modern chess are that the earlier game had a vizier instead of a queen, and an elephant instead of a bishop, and these pieces had much more limited movement than their modern counterparts. The pawn also lacked the double-step introductory move it has today, and furthermore, there was no castling.

While all this sounds very limiting, it can make a refreshing change from modern chess. Modern openings must be left behind, and the pace of the game is a little slower, the limited movement of the pieces allowing defenses to be set up before the opponent approaches to destroy them.

Shatranj Kamil was an early and largely unsuccessful attempt to expand the game of Shatranj.

item.description:
The game is something like the better-known game "Battleship." In this game the players mark three squares (of four places) that the other playing is trying to find by guessing. The boards are plastic coated on particle board and marked with a grease pencil.

It was also released as a pad of sheets to be used with a regular pencil (or possibly two pads in a box), which were more professionally produced.

This game is quite unique with its theme as it is about motor-cross, a discipline that game publishers typically overlook. The goal is to reach the finish first and to score the maximum number of points. Each player either controls 1 or 2 motor-cross bikes. Each team has a budget and the races consists of 2 matches, the winner is the player who has scored the highest number of points over the 2 matches. Apart from dice, the game also consists of cards and a 34 x 47 cm. board. Vintage game from the '80s.

Kropki (or "Dots" in English) is a paper and pencil game very popular play-during-lessons-in-school game. It seems this game was invented to play Go with paper and pencil - in contrast to Go you can surround empty spaces together with opponents dots, and the surrounded areas are off limits for the rest of the game. Go experience is helpful, but many tactics work differently.

There are Wikipedia articles in Polish and Russian and Czech.

You can also play online.

Here is an online interactive tutorial with problems to solve:
http://www.tochki.org/lesson/eng/index.html

item.description:
Traffic is a game about traveling in Switzerland. The board shows a route of 45 spaces. 8 of them are petrol stations, which can be extended to service stations. The background of the board shows a detailed road map of Switzerland.

Each player travels across the route with a car, that can be chosen from 22 car cards. Some cars have cheaper upkeep costs than others, but they will reduce the income received when they land on the profitable bank spaces on the board. But money can also be earned through petrol/service stations, obtained by correctly answering the question cards as well as by chance cards and the possession of special star chips.

These star chips are the main objective of the game, because the first player having 70000 francs in money plus 7 star chips, wins the game.

Traffic comes with some unusual components. First, there is a plastic bar with 23 holes. 
Rolling a glass marble in that bar replaces the roll of a die. Second, a 1.5 x 3 inch model car serves as challenge trophy. The winner gets this car until a next game is played. And third, 2x36 (traffic) question cards for children and adults are somewhat like a game in the game.

A Mexican trivia game based on Catholic religion. Questions are divided in two groups: Practice and Culture; Practice questions refer to activities and behavior related to the Catholic Church, while Culture questions refer to historical and general knowledge questions that are somewhat related to Catholic religion.
Multiplication Bingo is an educational children's version of Bingo, designed to teach children multiplication, while retaining the flavor of Bingo.

Players take on the role of Wally, the "mascot" Wallonia. Players roll and move around a map of Wallonia from city to city visiting specific sites before returning to the starting locality to finish play. Le Wallon is a children’s game meant to teach children about Wallonia, it's cities and it’s History.

(From publisher's website)

NOVENOP is an acronym created from the words NOun, VErb, NOun, and Phrase and is a board game for children of ages 6 and up. NOVENOPS! has 60 cards that help develop the player's ability to understand the basic elements of grammar. Gameplay is designed to continuously reinforce the sentence structure concepts...while word familiarity improves reading and writing skills. Not only is NOVENOPS! a great learning experience-it's a hilarious game!

WHAT MAKES THIS DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: Check Two Card.

When this Check Two Card played by a player, he/she can:
- immediately play another card of the same suit color, OR
- play either Wild or Wild Draw 4 Card, the wild color called must match the color of the Check Two Card played.

However, this Check Two Card cannot be played:
- on its own (without a card of the same suit color), OR
- as the last card in your hand.
If the Check Two Card is the last card in a player hand, he/she must take another card from the draw pile. If the card just drawn matches the suit color of the Check Two Card, he/she may directly play the Check Two Card, say UNO, and play the matching suit color card to complete the game.

ACTION FRONT! Watchtower is the first in a projected series of DTP microgames covering tactical combat in WWII. The game's expandable system is reminiscent of the venerable Panzerblitz/Panzer Leader games, with a feeling of the Five-Star series thrown in. Each game is played on 4 x 8 inch semi-geomorphic maps, with a fast, furious sequence of play that minimizes bookkeeping and maximizes the action. Players may play the included scenarios or create their own using the provided rules.

Watchtower comes with 20 US and 20 Japanese units, allowing players to recreate the epic struggle of the 1st US Marine Division on Guadalcanal in September and October of 1942. USMC Raiders and Paramarines square off against Chi-Ha tanks and leg mortars. Special rules are included for Henderson Field and banzai attacks.

In a small series with the Action Front! Hakko Ichiu.

name.value: The Berenstain Bears Spooky Old Tree Game

item.description: Take one of 4 bears and guide them through the spooky old tree. Help get them out by using their flashlight, stick, rope and key. First bear out wins.

name.value: The Berenstain Bears Missing Dinosaur Bone Game

item.description: Race through the rooms of the museum, finding all the missing objects. If you are the first to find a dinosaur bone and return it to its proper place, you win!

Le Combat de l’Aigle (The Eagle's fight) is a tactical game system meant to simulate Napoleonic battles at the battalion scale. Large size battles are playable in one day. The game mechanism is close to miniatures, but the armies are included in the box as are several scenarios on the beginning of the 1809 campaign. Other volumes will follow.

Several rules are very innovative; a focus on unit cohesion (visualized by file closers set behind the unit), the chain of command, a cavalry combat using waves of squadrons close to reality. Other elements, (e.g. the brigade move) can accelerate the game. The combat system is based on drawing cards and comparing them (a simpler system based on a single die roll is also included).

Le Combat de l’Aigle can be played three different ways :

* As a tactical system to simulate real or imaginary battles..
 * As a miniature game system (Kip Trexel is the author of the campaign rules for Empire III). Basing and the use of miniatures, with single miniatures as file closers, are easy to adapt to any scale. Designed at first to be played with 6mm miniatures and doubling all distances included here, it can be converted to any scale with great ease..
 * As a tactical extension of the Vol de lâ€™Aigle campaign system, to solve every important battle. The players can decide to switch to a more tactical system when a large battle occurs.

The game includes 5 scenarios on the opening moves of the 1809 campaign.
Content (under ziplock):

* 1 rule book (32 pages).
 * 18 hard paper counter sheets including the French and Austrian armies at the beginning of the 1809 campaign in Bavaria.
 * 4 sheets of colorful player aid.

The players must provide numerical markers from 1 to 6 (we use 5mm dice).

name.value: Under the Spell of the Pyramid

item.description:
You play an archaeologist in search of the kings chamber in a new pyramid that has been discovered. Using equipment you explore the hallways and chambers and get into one adventure after the other.

Contents:
5 adventure cards (both sides usable)
1 kings' chamber (both sides usable)
5 archaeologist in 5 different colors
1 warehouse
54 pyramid cards including:
 36 equipment cards
 18 special cards

Remake of Der Schatz des Pharaos with a few rules tweaks.

item.description: The original title of this cycling game is about a gear that can be selected on a bike. This French game appeared at the end of the '80s. The game contains 4 double sided big boards representing a Tour de France étappe on each one. It's played with 2 dice, 40 tactics cards, 32 mountain cards, 26 sprint cards and 30 rouleur cards. Every player gets a team of 3 plastic cyclists. In the beginning every player gets a number of tactical cards. Movement is decided by the dice and influenced by the cards. In the mountains the number rolled by the dice is divided by two. Cyclists can also encounter a flat tire (caused by rolling two 1's with the dice), if this happens to the team leader, he can be helped by a teammate if necessary. Winner is the player who scores best in the overall classification. There is also a mountain prize for the player who has the best climber in his team.

This game, releases either late '50s or early '60s, is in a very original format. The game has a 45rpm record (album size) with the instructions on it (side A contains a flat stage, side B a mountain stage), the gameboard is the backside of the record sleeve. The board has a drawing of France on it, with a track on the outside. Movement of the pawns is decided by dice rolling.

This German vintage cycling game dates back to the period between 1910 and 1920! It has two boxes, on with an oval indoor cycling track on it, the smaller box contains 12 metal cyclist. Players can either form a team of several cyclists or play just with one cyclist. Movement is decided by rolling 2 wooden hand made dice. There are six kind of disciplines that can be raced on the track : Sechstagerennen (6 day cycling), Fliegerennen (flying start), Auscheidungsfahren, Puntkefahren (points race), Dauerrennen (durability) & Mannschaftsrennen (teamrace).

This cycling game appeared somewhere in the 1970's in East Germany. The game has very original mechanics as the movement of the plastic cyclists on the oval indoor track on the gameboard is not done by cards or by dice but by a speedometer, a device that looks a bit like a spinner. That only makes this game a collectors item.

Not to be confused with 6-Tage Rennen.

Le Jeu des 7 Tours is a cycling game containing a large board measuring 69x49cms., 14 pawns (unfortunately no plastic cyclists, just classic pawns here), two dice and 70 cards with questions about cycling. In the game it is possible to enter 7 different races. These are the Tours of France, Spain, USA, Japan, Benelux, Italy or Columbia. The tracks of these races are compiled out of a combination of flat stages, time trials and mountain stages. Movement is decided by rolling 2 dice, when someone rolls a 7 he has to draw a card and answer a question about cycling. The winner is he who wins the overall classifying of all races.

name.value: Bicycle Race: A Game for the Wheelmen

item.description: This beautifully crafted vintage cycling game in a wooden box was produced in the USA at the end of the 19th century and truly a collectors item. There are 6 pawns, each representing a player. What makes it original is that movement is not decided by dice but by a spinning device (also ranging from 1 movement space to maximum 6). Every space on the board track also has text upon it, either giving the player luck or bad luck. Winner is the one who crosses the finish line first.

Cycling game released in the early '90s by a company from Valence (France) named Samourai to promote fruit from the Rhône-Alpes region in France. Each player has a team of 3 cyclists. The 4 available teams are the Apricots (orange color), Pêches (pink), Pommes-Poires (green with yellow) and the Petits fruits (red colored cyclists). There also are a cyclist with a yellow and green jersey for the leader in the classification (yellow general, green points). The mechanics are rather simple (dice rolling).

Small simple cycling game released by the Chad Valley Company released somewhere in the 1930's. Movement is decided by dice rolling, certain spaces have text in them that can cause bad luck. The game was released to promote the B.S.A. company who were well known for their motorbikes but they also had a range of bicycles in their catalog in those days.

name.value: Dschingis Khan: Bewegung an der Großen Mauer

item.description:
The great empires of China and Mongolia are divided by the Great Wall. Dzhingiz Khan, however, united the Mongolian tribes and is attempting to conquer China. In the resulting disorder warriors from both sides and farmers try to find safe places. Mongolian warriors want to be on the Mongolian side of the Great Wall, while Chinese warriors want to be on the Chinese side. Only farmers can be on both sides.

Dschingis Khan – Bewegung an der Großen Mauer is an abstract strategy game with a big dose of luck. Player place markers with warriors, farmers, the plague or a cure on spaces on the board. Whoever placed the top marker controls the pile. Points are awarded for warriors on the right side of the wall and (less) for farmers. However, the Wall can 'move': new walls can be built and parts of the old wall can be removed.

result.value: Some necessary text - easily memorized or small crib sheet
Moderate in-game text - needs crib sheet or paste ups
Extensive use of text - massive conversion needed to be playable

name.value: Butagaz (Le Tour de France du premier butane français)

item.description: Butagaz (subtitled 'Le Tour de France du premier butane français) was released in France in 1934 to promote the use of gas. The gameboard measures 37x28cms (A3 format). Movement of the pawns is decided by a die. As a curiosity, the cyclist who rejoins a Butagaz truck on a square advances two squares. The gameboard has a Tour de France map on it with the two Butagaz factories (in Paillac and Rouen) also mentioned on it. Winner is the player who's pawn reaches Paris first.

This game had several releases. It was originally released by Spika, a game publisher from Karl-Marx-Stadt (now Chemnitz) in East Germany (DDR). Bunte Trikots is a cycling game with a 47x34cm. board with an indoor oval cycling track (with 100 spaces) on it. The original version from 1959 had a blue background, the 1964 version a grey background. In the '60s a Belgian version (also with a blue background) was released in both French and Dutch language. There are 6 plastic cyclists (one for each player) that move after rolling a die. There are different rules for in total 5 different disciplines that can be raced on the track. Vintage game for collectors and cycling lovers.
